pageData.text: <button className='glossary-text'>Saponification</button> is the chemical process that is used to produce soap. However, there is another product that benefits from this reaction mechanism – the fire extinguisher. Some types of fire, such kitchen fires involving cooking fats and oils, burn hotter than those caused by other flammable substances. These fires are not affected by standard fire extinguishers. Firefighters have found that such extremely hot fires are best put out by wet chemical extinguishers rather than the dry chemical extinguishers used for paper, wood, and plastic fires. Wet chemical extinguishers leverage the saponification reaction to turn burning oil into non-flammable soap. As the reaction cools, it emulsifies the burning substance, causing the flames to die out. Additional chemicals within the extinguisher go on to create a seal over the surface of the once-burning substance to prevent reignition.

pageData.text: Soap production has been a part of human culture for thousands of years, dating at least as far back as 2800 BCE in Babylon. Typical recipes consisted of animal fats and potash (a name referring to the residue of a fire below a cooking pot), which is the ashes of burned vegetation, most commonly trees. Potash contains large quantities of <button className='glossary-text'>sodium hydroxide</button>, which, when added to animal fat, results in <button className='glossary-text'>saponification</button>.

pageData.text: Figure 1 shows an example of a <button className='glossary-text'>triglyceride</button>(fat) composed of the fatty acids, the tails of this molecule, palmitic acid (top), lauric acid (middle), and myristic acid (bottom).

Saponification is a type of base <button className='glossary-text'>hydrolysis reaction</button> whereby the addition of sodium hydroxide (or another strong base) to a fat (triglyceride) produces <button className='glossary-text'>glycerol</button> and <button className='glossary-text'>soap molecules</button>, which are the salts of the fatty acids cleaved from the glycerol molecule (Figure 2).

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Reaction of tristearin with sodium hydroxide to produce glycerol and sodium stearate using condensed structural formula

pageData.text: The process of occurs in . The traditional soap-making process utilizes a high concentration (more than 6 Molar) of . The high concentration of hydroxide ion (OH−) helps push the reaction toward completion, the right-hand side of the reaction shown in . Generally, heat is applied to the reaction to promote rapid soap formation. The high concentration of base and high heat required in the “hot process” makes it unsuitable as an in-home activity.

In Activity 1, soap will be created through a cold process. In the cold process, heat is required only for melting the fat used (if it is solid at room temperature). The vegetable oil that will be used in Activity 1 is liquid at room temperature, so heat is not required. A lower concentration (1 M instead of 6+ M) of sodium hydroxide will be used in order to limit exposure to corrosive materials. This substitution will result in a soap that is less solid than a traditional bar soap. The sodium hydroxide and oil will be mixed in a vial to allow for thorough mixing of the chemicals. Without mixing, the aqueous sodium hydroxide and the oil would separate into two layers. With thorough mixing, an is formed. In an emulsion, microscopic droplets of oil are suspended in the water, allowing for a greater surface area upon which the sodium hydroxide and oil can react.

After 72 hours, the soap solution can be rinsed with sodium chloride solution in a process referred to as <button className='glossary-text'>“salting out”</button> the soap. The addition of sodium chloride helps the <button className='glossary-text'>soap molecules</button> separate from the water and allows for easier filtering at the end of Activity 1.

pageData.text: Activity 2 will focus on the properties of soaps. Soaps have several properties that affect their use. For example, the pH of a soap is important, as a high pH will make the soap corrosive and cause severe irritation when used on the skin. Soaps with a pH between 7 and 9 are generally considered safe for use on skin.

Soaps are most effective at removing oil or grease. The long nonpolar tails of <button className='glossary-text'>soap molecules</button> interact with the fats and oils to be removed. The polar heads of the soap molecules are attracted to the water used for rinsing. The soap molecules surround the drop of oil, creating a bubble of soap called a <button className='glossary-text'>micelle</button> (Figure 3), which can be rinsed away with water.

In hard water (water containing high concentrations of calcium or magnesium ions), soap becomes less effective. The calcium and magnesium ions react with the soap, displacing the sodium ions and forming an insoluble solid, most commonly referred to as soap scum. More soap is required produce a foamy lather with hard water, as the soap reacts first with the calcium and magnesium ions.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Image of soap molecules forming a micelle around an oil droplet. The long hydrophobic tails of the soap point inward toward the oil droplet.

pageData.desc: This map describes the workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will combine vegetable oil and sodium hydroxide in a vial and shake it vigorously until an emulsion forms. Then, you will let the vial rest for 72 hours before filtering its contents. Next, you will add a sodium chloride solution to the vial, which you will shake vigorously before filtering the vial contents. Finally, you will let the collected soap rest. In Activity 2, you will create a mixture of the soap and water and add some of the mixture into two test tubes. You will determine the pH of test tube 1, shake the tube vigorously and observe the foam layer, and add vegetable oil to the tube, shake vigorously and observe the foam layer. Lastly, you will add hard water to test tube 2, then shake the tube vigorously and observe the foam layer.

pageData.text: Place the empty dram vial and cap on the balance and tare the balance.
Using a pipet, dispense about 2 g of vegetable oil into the vial.
In the 10-mL graduated cylinder, measure 2 mL of the 1 M <button className='glossary-text'>sodium hydroxide</button>.
Pour the sodium hydroxide into the dram vial and secure the cap tightly. There should be two distinct layers: the oil layer and the sodium hydroxide layer.
Shake the dram vial vigorously until an <button className='glossary-text'>emulsion</button> is formed and there are no distinct layers visible, this can take 5 to 10 minutes.
Allow the mixture to stand for 10 minutes, then shake the vial again until there are no distinct layers.
Place the vial in a secure location and allow the reaction to proceed for at least 72 hours. The vial can sit indefinitely until time allows for the completion of the activity.
After 72 hours, a solid will have formed at the interface between the oil and sodium hydroxide layers.
Place the plastic funnel (stem down) into the 100-mL beaker.
Fold the filter paper as shown in Figure 4, and place it into the funnel.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Diagram and photo showing how to fold filter paper and place it into the funnel.

pageData.text: Preparing a Filtration Funnel
Pour the solution from the vial onto the filter paper in the funnel.
With the 10-mL graduated cylinder, measure 2 mL of 25% sodium chloride solution.
Pour the sodium chloride solution into the vial, cap the vial, and shake vigorously.
Uncap the vial and pour the solution onto the filter paper in the funnel.
Add an additional 2 mL of 25% sodium chloride to the vial, shake, and pour onto the filter paper.
Remove the filter paper with the soap from the funnel and place it on several paper towels until Activity 2 is to be performed. Preferably, let it rest overnight.
In Activity 2, you will analyze the properties of your prepared soap sample. As an optional activity, you can analyze the properties of a household soap sample for comparison.
Scrape the soap from the filter paper with a spoon and weigh 0.5 g of soap and place it into the 100-mL beaker.
Measure 50 mL of purified water with the 50-mL graduated cylinder.
Add the purified water to the 100-mL beaker.
With the grease pencil, label the test tubes as #1 and #2.
With a 10-mL graduated cylinder, measure 5 mL of soap solution into each test tube and place them in the test tube rack.
Take the glass stirring rod and dip it into the solution in test tube #1, then touch the stirring rod to a piece of pH paper. Compare the color to the pH chart and record the pH in the Data Table.
Place your gloved thumb on top of test tube #1; make sure your thumb has made a good seal with the vial, and shake vigorously for 10 seconds.
Take a photo of the foam layer produced.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: With a pipet, add 2 drops of vegetable oil to test tube #1, cover the opening with a gloved thumb, and shake for 10 seconds.
Take a photo of the foam layer produced.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Open the hard water mix packet and pour the mix into the 50-mL graduated cylinder.
Fill the 50-mL graduated cylinder with purified water to the 50-mL mark. Pour the contents of the cylinder into the beaker.
Stir carefully with the glass stirring rod.
With a plastic pipet, dispense 20 drops of hard water solution into test tube #2.
Using your gloved thumb to create a seal with test tube #2, shake for 10 seconds.
Take a photo of the foam layer produced.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Thoroughly rinse the graduated cylinder, beaker, test tubes, and pipets with water.
Optional: Repeat Activity 2 using a 1-g sample of the household soap in step 1.

data.title: Glycerol

data.title: Micelle

data.title: Salting out
data.content: Soap solution is rinsed with sodium chloride solution, helps the soap molecules separate from the water and allows for easier filtering
